story:
What is Emerging Artists Zine?

Emerging Artists Zine (EAZ) is a zine dedicated to giving first-timers in the zine community the chance to shine. Each volume is a different theme. The theme for this volume is Witching Hour: witches, wizards, and all things magical.

  • Witching Hour is run by a team of 5 zine mods with varying levels of experience from newbies to veterans. All of us are passionate about zines and are so excited to release this beautiful book to the world.
  • Each one of us believes that every talented artist deserves the chance to be in a zine if they want to be. 
  • By supporting EAZ, you're supporting each and every emerging artist involved!
  • To view the list of contributors for Witching Hour, please see here: Contributor List 
    (please note, 3 of the people on that list have since dropped out).

Zine Specifications and Funds

Each digital and physical copy of the zine comes with 40+ original pieces of beautiful witch-and-wizard themed artwork from 35+ extremely talented new artists breaking into the zine community.

Zine specifications:

  • 8.5"x11" (US Letter sized)
  • Perfect bound
  • Soft cover
  • Around 60 pages total, give or take a few pages

Our goal is to receive enough funding to cover physical production costs of the zine, and to be able to provide each amazing and hard-working contributor with their compensation of a physical zine free of charge.

Each penny received from the zine will go towards these things: 

  • Physical zine printing and production costs
  • Shipping costs and supplies
  • Platform fees
  • Applicable taxes
  • Our chosen charity: Pencils of Promise

If the project is not fully funded, we unfortunately will not be able to produce physical copies of the zine. In the case that the project is not funded, backers of the physical zine will receive:

  • A partial refund for the cost difference between physical vs. digital zine  ($10+shipping refund for the Merlin Bundle, $15+shipping refund for the Morgana Bundle)
  • A digital PDF copy of the zine

If the physical zine is not funded, ALL profits from the zine will go towards our charity, Pencils of Promise.

Our chosen charity: Pencils of Promise

As stated above, all the profits (after production costs) will go towards Pencils of Promise. Pencils of Promise is a charity organization that builds schools and funds education in Ghana, Guatemala, and Laos. So for backing this project, not only will you receive a gorgeous zine, but you will also be able to say that you contributed to a good cause.

For more information about Pencils of Promise, please visit their website: https://pencilsofpromise.org/

The Next Step (after the campaign is finished)

If the zine campaign is fully funded, we will move forward with these steps:

  • We will order first physical proofs of the zine from our printer. Once that is approved, we will proceed with printing and shipping.
  • All of the physical zines will be shipped to one of the mods, where they will be packaged and shipped.
  • We are aiming to have all packages shipped sometime in December or hopefully, maybe even earlier than that!
  • PDF orders will be sent via email around when people would be receiving their physical zines.
  • We will calculate how much is leftover after production costs and give the rest of the proceeds made to charity.

If the zine campaign is NOT fully funded, we will move forward with these steps:

  • We will issue partial refunds to those who backed the physical zine perks (Morgana or Merlin bundles).
  • PDF zine will be sent out as soon as all refunds have been processed. 
  • We will give all proceeds from the campaign to charity, with none going to production (since the physical zine will not be made).

After the first round of everything has been distributed, we are considering doing a 2nd round of PDF sales. However, we have no plans currently to do another round of physical sales for the zine so get the physical zine while you can!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support the zine by buying a bundle but you still want to contribute, there are other ways you can support us!

  • Share our campaign with anyone and everyone you know that you think would be interested. Word of mouth does wonders!
  • Support independent artists by sharing their work - reblogging, retweeting, and showing your friends their work is the best way to support non-monetarily. Let your favorite artists know how much you love their work by commenting once in a while (even if they don't respond, they appreciate every positive comment received)!
  • Consider donating even a small amount to Pencils of Promise - every dollar counts!

Share our campaign with anyone and everyone you know that you think would be interested. Word of mouth does wonders!
Support independent artists by sharing their work - reblogging, retweeting, and showing your friends their work is the best way to support non-monetarily. Let your favorite artists know how much you love their work by commenting once in a while (even if they don't respond, they appreciate every positive comment received)!
Consider donating even a small amount to Pencils of Promise - every dollar counts!

story:
About Us

Magnificent Revolution is an education and art project based in the UK and Australia that turn bicycles into electricity generators for events, workshops and art installations.  In 2012 we are teaming up with artists across Europe to take pedal power on the road, in our biodiesel van, from London to Bratislava. 

What We Are Doing

Magnificent Revolution has been invited by Orbis Institute in Slovakia to travel over and upgrade their pedal power system.  We thought we should use this opportunity to take pedal power to other countries and hold off grid bike powered events and workshops along the way.

In 2012 we will work with artists Holland, Austria, Germany before delivering the enormous 20-bike generator to our pedal power friends in Slovakia.  This follows on from our adventures in 2011, when we worked in Hong Kong building a 4-bike generator kit and toured pedal powered cinema around the city.  We left 4 generators with 4 enthusiastic groups there to do their own off grid events.

Why this project is awesome is because we are demonstrating the possibilities of renewable clean energy with fun and engaging mediums with free screenings, stages and art installations for audiences to actively participate in.  We will be hosting workshops on the tour as well, showing others how to build a pedal power system themselves.  Leaving a legacy is important to us.

What We Need & What You Get

We will be traveling from London to deliver a spankin' new 20 bike system to Bratislava.  For this we will need funding for

-       Provisions for our workshop attendees – we want to make them free to everyone.

-       Funding for materials for our installation

-       Bio diesel for our van

-       Food for our tummies

-       Covering event costs like venue hire and licences

The Impact

Your contribution will make this exciting adventure possible!

  • We have hosted pedal power projects in Sweden, Greece, Hong Kong, Kazakhstan, Australia and Slovakia.  Slovakia is going so well, they need a bigger pedal power system!
  • We will be educating others with our hands on workshops and demonstrating pedal power in action at our events.
  • This project will make a valuable contribution to our new audience’s experience of renewable energy and help them imagine a sustainable world.
  • We will be collaborating with fellow artists along the way – who knows what amazing possibilities that will reap!

MR is proud of a track record that has so far helped to educate thousands of school children about energy consumption and renewable technology. We have replaced conventional power with people powered energy at over 200 music, film and art events. So far we have helped thousands individuals to conceptualise energy, and learn about appliance and electronic equipment power consumption through our events.

If you can’t contribute financially, then help get the word out!

In Australia:

Web - www.magrev.org.au

Facebook -  http://www.facebook.com/MagnificentRevolutionAU

Twitter - @MagRevAU

In the UK

Web - www.magnificentrevolution.org

Facebook - http://www.facebook.com/magnificentrevolution

Twitter - @magrevlondon

story:
WOULD LIKE TO RAISE FUNDS TO BE ABLE

 TO TAKE THE QUILT ON TOUR.

  

PLEASE SHARE

NEED TO BE ABLE TO RENT A SPACE AND FIXTURES

TO DISPLAY THE 200 QUILTS PROPERLY.

EACH BLOCK WAS DONATED AND MADE BY PEOPLE

ACROSS THE WORLD. THE NAMES OF VICTIMS WERE

WRITTEN ON BLOCKS.

THEN VOLUNTEERS SEWED THE BLOCKS TOGETHER

AND THEY WERE THEN MACHINE QUILTED.

DONATIONS IN ANY AMOUNT IS ALWAYS, AND

GREATLY APPRECIATED

THANK YOU

story:
It creeps through our fair city, picking up passengers (up to 200) along the way, including wheeled passengers who can enter via the rear drawbridge. It arrives in deep playa and parks. A friendly battle ensues (costumes and props in storage on board). A banquet is set, and a celebratory dinner ensues for all, followed of course by a dance party.

While it is in motion the driver of the castle car will be sitting on its front balcony. This balcony will also accommodate live performers, including bands and dancers. This balcony will be designed so that performances can be directed into the castle or out toward the city.

Phase One:    We need a truck

We will use a semi truck as the basic frame and drive train for our future ride.   This is where it all begins.  The truck is the first and most important step to get started.    A Semi truck without the trailer would be an ideal platform for the castle to be built on. The semi would be used to haul the structure to the event site, to be assembled on location. This would simplify transportation to and from any events we might wish to take it to.  

Estimated Expense:  $5000

This campaign will help us fund Phase One.  Once we purchase the truck then we can move on to Phase Two.

Phase Two:  Let's Build a Castle

We will be repurposing the towers and framework from the  11:11 monument which we brought to BRC in 2011. These parts can be used to help make a frame for the floor and the four corners of the castle. We imagine this castle to have flags flying high with flame effects from the tops of the flag poles and propane powered torch lamps providing the castle with some ambiance.

The draw bridge will be functional and the entire castle will be designed to be wheelchair accessible. The drawbridge will be designed so that it will smooth and flatten a path as the Castle Car moves, leaving what will resemble a road leading to our castle.

Estimated Expense:  $27,000

Phase Three: The Dragon!

Our vision of this castle has a dragon perched on top of it as though the castle were under attack. The castle will be under the control of Vikings engaged in celebration. The dragon will have an animated head, neck and tail and of course will breathe fire. When the dragon breathes it will produce a menacing screeching sound.

Estimated Expense:  $10,000 to 27,000


Building a project such as this will take many hours of planning and fabrication. We believe that our group can create the castle portion of this project before the next burn. The dragon will take an additional year to complete. 

Besides the obvious costs associated with making this structure like plywood, steel, paint and fasteners, there are other costs to consider. These include transportation costs both getting to the event and during, electricity for the work facility during construction, fuel for generators, propane for flame effects and many other expenses.

With funds in this range, ws could produce a reliable, durable and safe castle artcar for at least 100, and up to 200, passengers to enjoy for many years. The cost range reflects the different options available for construction and design features as well as the quantity and quality of amenities. Some things such as a sound system could possibly be donated. The cost estimates do not reflect that possibility. Flame effects and sound systems could be eliminated; this would reduce the overall cost.

We are very willing and able to provide  the labor and facilities to make this a reality. We have a great team with the skills and drive to make it happen.  We appreciate your help!

story:
I love pirates or at least the myth that television and movies have portrayed to us. The whole thought of searching for buried treasure. Looking back at all the different paths life has taken me has been like a map leading me to small treasures. Now I'm on my journey for finding the big treasure and I want all of you to be a part of it with me. At the end I will succeed in uncovering it and I will be sharing it with all of you.

This is the first set of an ongoing pirate series. I will release the next set at the same events next year. All of the funding will go towards the shipping, scanning, and printing of all my pieces. I have five different pieces, three water color paintings and two charcoal drawings in my first set and I'm going to get them printed. I have upcoming release events scheduled in August, September, and October in Pennsylvania.


Nathan R Williams

© 20140531

“The Hunt Begins”

Captain of a ship writes down where they have hidden the ships treasure for fear of being raided by pirates in the area

Original Drawing

Water Color on 140lb Cold Press Paper

16" x 20”

#1 in The Acacia Treasure print series of The Pyrates Collection




Nathan R Williams © 20140626

“Ship’s Rage”

The fiendish Pyrates have found them and unleashes its fury upon them.

Original Drawing

Charcoal on 96lb Textured Bristol Paper

19" x 24”

#2 in The Acacia Treasure print series of The Pyrate Collection



Nathan R Williams © 20140614

“Captain Christian”

Captain of the Pyrates goes aboard the helpless ship to see whats worth taken when he comes across the letter from the other Captain about the location of the ships treasure.

Original Drawing

Charcoal on 96lb Textured Bristol Paper

24 x 19”

#3 in The Acacia Treasure print series of The Pyrate Collection



Nathan R Williams © 20140619

“Deciphering the Code”

The Captain has to try and figure out what the code on the compass means if he is to ever find the ships buried treasure.

Original Drawing

Mixed Media - Watercolor and Ink on 140lb Cold Press Paper

20" x 30”

#4 in The Acacia Treasure print series of The Pyrate Collection



Nathan R Williams © 20140610

“Acacia Island”

After finally cracking the code on the map the Pyrates make their way to the island.

Original Drawing

Watercolor on 140lb Cold Press Paper

16" x 20”

#5 in The Acacia Treasure print series of The Pyrate Collection

story:
SHE’S GONNA FLY!


  Hello! I'm Caroline Paquita, a visual artist, musician, bee-keeper, and in general, a maker and “sharer” of things. I live and work out of Port Quincy, in Brooklyn, NY. After many years of self-publishing, I'm officially beginning a small queer, feminist, total-art-freaker publishing house called PEGACORN PRESS. Through your help, I’m hoping to raise funds for new and better equipment to make this easier and all the more possible.

  This tiny and unique publishing house will specialize in small-run art books, comics and zines. In the DIY vein of things, I've been creating thousands of copies of work, on an extremely "scrappy" budget for a long time now. I'm beginning this campaign to gather funds to buy necessary supplies (a better paper-cutter, folding machine, heavy duty stapler, binding equipment) and WHOA! possibly even a newer and better operating duplicator. Besides the printing, everything I do- from collating, stapling, folding and hole punching- is done by hand. This is a very laborious and time consuming labor of love that can be hard on the body, but I’m hoping to remedy that a bit with some helpful supplies.

  For over a decade, I've made zines and have regularly had my work printed and shown in galleries. PEGACORN PRESS has been a long time in the making and is informed directly from the DIY punk, queer, feminist, art world that I live and engage in. In 2009, I bought my first Risograph duplicator, which is a machine that looks very much like a copier, but technologically speaking, is one step up from a mimeograph. A high speed machine, a Risograph can print between 60-120 prints per minute. Essentially, the process is similar to screen-printing, except done automatically and all within a relatively small machine.  

  Different colored inks can be used in dedicated color drums, but due to the fact that my machine is older, quality issues usually start to come up after two colors are printed. At this point, it’s easier to use my machine for strictly one color jobs, though the option to use black, red, burgandy, purple or blue ink is there. Ideally, I wouldn't have problems, but considering that this beast of a machine is from the early 1980's (and has made over 2.5 million copies), it's hard to complain since it’s made it this far and is still working. While I’ll keep working this Risograph til it breaks down for good (said with fingers crossed since that’s all I have to work with right now...), a better working machine would definitely be helpful and would be the “big” purchase of this fundraising. Even if the goal isn’t met, donations will definitely help obtain any, or even all, of the smaller items needed to put everything together without breaking my back any more than it already is!

  

COMING UP THIS FALL...


  Recently, I was awarded an artist's residency in Halifax, Nova Scotia at the Roberts Street Social Centre. Based on my proposal for a “Punk Health” zine and for the necessary time to work on the second issue of WOMANIMALISTIC (a comic-zine), I’ll be heading up there in October to live in a “rustic” shack behind the bustling RSSC, which also houses the Anchor Archive Zine Library. The third and upcoming 2012 Paquita calendar, as well as the comic compilation (assuming that all the contributors get their stuff in by the deadline!) will be printed in time to take to Halifax. A big zine conference and a music festival will be happening when I’m there, so all around it’s a great opportunity for not only my own artistic practice, but to share PEGACORN PRESS with a larger audience. Prior to leaving for all this excitement in Nova Scotia, a New York release party is being planned to celebrate all the new projects coming out. Last year a friend and I had a dual-release party (for the 2011 Calendar, WOMANIMALISTIC and his zine, Slice Harvester) at The City Reliquary, which was a well received and successful event.


THE IMPACT...


 With PEGACORN PRESS, the hope is that any funds raised from projects printed, will help fuel the next one in line (and/or purchase other helpful equipment), in order to help expand the press and it’s capabilities. The plan isn’t to have a huge operation or distribution going (I plan on keeping my “real-world” jobs), but to infrequently publish- two to four times a year- works that are interesting, inspiring and need to see the light of day.

  I live in a world surrounded by other artists who make incredibly beautiful, intelligent and amazingly funny work that the world deserves to see more of. I've found that more often than not, people who lead "unconventional lifestyles" and who have more radical politics, are less likely to have their work published. Women and queers are noticeably absent from this world and I’d like to change that as much as I can through not only art, but the art of dissemination. From my own experiences, I know that many projects are started, but never make it to the printer due to finances, time and other circumstances. I'd like to help create an environment where artists are able to have the luxury to make work that will get printed and done so in a creative way.

  Currently, I keep an Etsy store and also sell to small bookstores around the country. Publications out on PEGACORN PRESS will also be sold online, in stores, have release parties, and possibly small tours to promote their existence. As someone who has been involved with a collectively run non-profit, and has booked, toured, and sold my own work around the world, I feel confident that what gets printed, will actually get out on the streets. I want people to be inspired and to learn from other folks, not only through the written word, but through art! To be able to share the resources, as well as learn some new processes along the way is the root of this campaign.


What is Needed...



   All equipment I buy is done after careful researching and consideration. Most of it is found used via Craigslist or on Ebay and I’m constantly on the lookout for good deals. Since costs are dependent on many factors, it’s hard to give a hard amount on the things I need, but here’s some rough estimates:


Better, larger paper-cutter: $100-200


Heavy duty, long-arm stapler: $100-200


Paper folder: $200-400


Dependent on the style, the cost of binding equipment can be all over the place. Currently I’m looking for a machine that is heavy duty enough to stitch up small books. If I can’t find that for a reasonable cost, hand-binding is still an option, but it would be nice to have the appropriate tools to do it since it’s time consuming.

Estimated cost, anywhere between $100-1,000


A newer Risograph duplicator, with several drums: $600-1,200


  In the totally wild possibility that my goal is exceeded, any extra money would be used to purchase a set or two of wooden letter-press font for a small letterpress that I also have. After the initial equipment I’m seeking is purchased and P.P. is thriving, this will be the next adventure into the world of publishing. One can vision quest, right? That’s where everything begins...


What You Get...


Gifts! Everyone who donates, actually gets real objects sent to them in the mail, as well as being listed as a donor on the P.P. website. I love sending mail and feel like if you’re going to take the trouble to help me out, then you deserve to get something real in your hand. The point of this project is to make REAL OBJECTS and it would be crazy to give you anything otherwise.

Every single donation will be truly appreciated and will help this crazy little beast become a reality!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this project and help me get the word out! Facebook! Tumbler! Other Internet sites that I have no idea about! Telephone banks! Fax! Snail mail! Carrier Pigeons! There’s only so much I can do, especially when I need to be adamantly drawing every waking hour for the next few months to get all this done in time to leave for Halifax. Thank you in advance for helping spread the word, seriously.


With MEGA LOVE-

Caroline Paquita


P.S. In the off chance that you have any equipment that I’m looking for, or anything that would be helpful in a printshop that you’d like to donate to P.P., please contact me. Even crazier, if you live in the NYC area and happen to have a warehouse of paper suitable for printing- definitely get in touch. No matter what, every job can’t start until the paper arrives...

story:
Our Story

Almost a year ago, my career brought me to Newark, New Jersey. It was then I was introduced to the idea of a Newark School. The Newark School is a population of artists whose work is primarily informed by its environment - with a great deal if these artists being self-taught.  As an arts administrator, artist, and cultural researcher I have become enamored by the rich history among the Black artist community in Newark.  What I find most intriguing about this community of artists is its close proximity to New York City, yet its ability to maintain its own identity and unique way of sustaining itself.  I have had many informal conversations about the history of Black artists in Newark which has guided me to dig deeper and archive these legacies.

 

Because of the warmth, I've received from this  community; I'm embarking on an oral history project, The Newark Black Artists (NBA) Oral History Project, that pays homage to such rich legacies.  This oral history project will chronicle each personality each journey, and each  contribution of the Black visual artists in Newark.

 

The Impact

The Newark Black Artists (NBA) Oral History Project is dedicated to collecting and preserving first-hand narratives of Black visual artists from and/or currently located in the City of Newark, New Jersey.  Through artist's accounts, we expand the art history canon to include emerging and established intergenerational Black artists in Newark.  We do this with the understanding that these artists are a part of a vibrant community and essential to providing cultural, historical, and societal commentary.  Our goal is to capture, bring public awareness to and promote the careers of Newark Black artists.

What We Need & What You Get

The funds raised go directly to the artists and to the preservation of their stories. With  this money we intend to offer honorariums to the participating artists.  We also will build a website for the world to have access to this information.  Reliable equipment to capture these stories is needed. Every dollar counts.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways you can help:

1 - Donate to this campaign and spread the word!

 

2. Participate  - If you are an artist and would like to participate, send us an email.  Also send us your exhibition announcements and images of your work. Nbaoralhistory@gmail.com 

 

3. Like us on facebook. http://www.facebook.com/pages/Newark-Black-Visual-Artists-Oral-History-Project/263243540409835

story:
Hello!  My name is Coral and I am an artist/designer with a small business called Squared Array.  I make fun, unique and versatile modern designs for the home and office.  I have been doing well in sales recently and am looking to further expand my business and artistic skillsets.  I heard about the Camp which is a 4 day and 3 night workshop in Big Bear, CA that is a gathering of like-minded creators and small business owners in the arts. 

This is of great importance to me as growing a small business in the handmade art industry is challenging.  I am hoping to find local small business support resources within the art community, build relationships that lead to potential artistic collaborations, and learn some new creative skillsets at the Camp conference.  This is also part of my business 3-5 year plan.  I had expected to pay for this myself but I have had to invest in my business recently in order to produce a large amount of orders that came in from a few websites that my pieces were on - this is a good thing of course.  However, it will take a few months before I make that money back and by then the conference I am hoping to attend will be over. 

The funding I am requesting will go to Camp registration which is $1,200.  This covers the following:

- new ideas

- hands-on workshops and classes

- key note speakers from the industry

- food/room and board

- networking with like minded peers

- leadership skills

more information on the Camp website

http://www.theuniquecamp.com/

If I don't reach my goal of the registration amount I will assess if I can come up with the rest I am short on and cover that portion. If I am not able to come up with the rest I will put the amount into my business to purchase a few woodworking tools I need for my modern wood art pieces. 

Any help is greatly appreciated even if it is just forwarding onto others who may want to contribute towards small business development in handmade arts.

story:
Hi,

My name is Sevan Injejikian and I am an independent curator as well as the assistant coordinator of the Contemporary Art Galleries Association (AGAC) in Montreal.

Photographer Annie Sakkab and I are curating an exhibition together which has been selected as a featured show in this year's CONTACT 2013 Photography Festival in Toronto and which will help launch the Riverdale Hub's new Community Art Gallery.

The project:

Dislocations is an exhibition that brings together established and emerging artists Annie Sakkab, Mona Kamal, Jin-me Yoon, Brett Gundlock, Jamelie Hassan, Khadija Baker and Meral Pasha who explore experiences of migration and consider how we negotiate a place for ourselves from one social environment to another.

The exhibition will launch the opening of the new Riverdale Hub Community Art Gallery and its arts programming which is geared towards community development. Located in the heart of Little India in Toronto, the Riverdale Hub provides invaluable hands-on training opportunities to marginalized women and their families, enabling them to develop sustainable livelihoods.

With your contribution, we will be able to establish a new gallery in the heart of Little India, further the Hub's goal of engaging the community in dialogue through art, and present the work of 7 established and emerging contemporary artists who address experiences of migration.

Why donate:

We need to raise nearly $6000 to cover costs for this project. Funding for this project will help transform the gallery into a professional exhibition space for future exhibitions. It will ensure that the gallery can:

- provide current and future exhibiting artists with proper lighting

- offer basic audio-visual equipment

- and become a creative environment and a space for dialogue between the women who frequent the centre and the community at large

Your contribution will also go towards:

- Dislocations' production costs (catalogue and promotional material)

- financial support to its exhibiting artists

For every contribution, you will receive a gift:

- As a thank you for contributions between $25 - $75, we will offer a special exhibition invitation card signed by the curators.

- For contributions between $75 - $200, we will offer a signed 8 x 10" print by one of the exhibiting artists.

- For contributions of $200 and over, you will receive a limited edition of the exhibition catalogue which includes artist statements, biographies and images of the works exhibited.

 

Thank you for your consideration and support!

 

If you can't contribute, please help us get the word out about our campaign by sending this email to friends, family or colleagues!

To do so, you can use the Indiegogo share tools or forward this message.
story_txt:
Hi,
My name is Sevan Injejikian and I am an independent curator as well as the assistant coordinator of the Contemporary Art Galleries Association (AGAC) in Montreal.
Photographer Annie Sakkab and I are curating an exhibition together which has been selected as a featured show in this year's CONTACT 2013 Photography Festival in Toronto and which will help launch the Riverdale Hub's new Community Art Gallery.
The project:
Dislocations is an exhibition that brings together established and emerging artists Annie Sakkab, Mona Kamal, Jin-me Yoon, Brett Gundlock, Jamelie Hassan, Khadija Baker and Meral Pasha who explore experiences of migration and consider how we negotiate a place for ourselves from one social environment to another. 
The exhibition will launch the opening of the new Riverdale Hub Community Art Gallery and its arts programming which is geared towards community development. Located in the heart of Little India in Toronto, the Riverdale Hub provides invaluable hands-on training opportunities to marginalized women and their families, enabling them to develop sustainable livelihoods.
With your contribution, we will be able to establish a new gallery in the heart of Little India, further the Hub's goal of engaging the community in dialogue through art, and present the work of 7 established and emerging contemporary artists who address experiences of migration.
Why donate:
We need to raise nearly $6000 to cover costs for this project. Funding for this project will help transform the gallery into a professional exhibition space for future exhibitions. It will ensure that the gallery can:
- provide current and future exhibiting artists with proper lighting
- offer basic audio-visual equipment
- and become a creative environment and a space for dialogue between the women who frequent the centre and the community at large
Your contribution will also go towards:
- Dislocations' production costs (catalogue and promotional material)
- financial support to its exhibiting artists
For every contribution, you will receive a gift:
- As a thank you for contributions between $25 - $75, we will offer a special exhibition invitation card signed by the curators.
- For contributions between $75 - $200, we will offer a signed 8 x 10" print by one of the exhibiting artists.
- For contributions of $200 and over, you will receive a limited edition of the exhibition catalogue which includes artist statements, biographies and images of the works exhibited.
 
Thank you for your consideration and support!
 
If you can't contribute, please help us get the word out about our campaign by sending this email to friends, family or colleagues!
To do so, you can use the Indiegogo share tools or forward this message.

story:
Short Summury

Born in Athens in 1970, and currently residing in the city of Volos, Greece, i’m a top graduate of the «Saint Luc» Higher School of Plastic Arts in Brussels, where i studied Art and Graphic Arts from 1988 to 1994. While still an art student I participated in various art contests achieving many awards and distinctions. I have been professionally painting since 2008. Since 2011, i’m member of the political cartoon association «Cartoon Movement», Amsterdam.

Paper, along with markers and blank ink (materials I’ve chosen to use), as well as the repeat of patterns transform my memory into shape and color and give to my paintings a childish naivety. According to a Greek saying: Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings comes forth the truth. Learning my own truth through my paintings, there are moments that I have an urge to publish and share it with people. I feel that this is the moment to publish and share my paintings for the first time outside my small country's borders. This was my dream for many many years and finally now I have the opportunity to make it come true. I was accepted by a very famous gallery in New York - http://www.agora-gallery.com - to exhibit my artwork after many efforts for many years.

Unfortunatelly this unique opportunity came in a very difficult time for me and my country in general. As you all may know the economic status of Greeks this period of time is extremely low and restricted. This opportunity maybe the first and yet the last one to make my dream come true and that is the reason why this campaign is very important to me. Besides I feel that I have the duty to support my country's reputation abroad with all my means, my ART!

What We Need & What You Get

The amount of funding that is needed for my campaign is 6850$ and this is the standard option someone can choose, in order to take part in a collective exhibition at Agora Gallery.

REPRESENTATION OPTIONS: Standard Representation
18 Months of Promotion with One Exhibition:
[ ] 1 Payment = $6,850
[ ] 3 Month Payment Plan -------- 3 x $2,365 = $7,095
[ ] 6 Month Payment Plan -------- 6 x $1,220 = $7,320

I would love to be grateful with people who will also be generous with me by funding my campaign. For that reason I have made a kind of a small art shop of the perks you may have for your contribution. I have designed a series of 16 artworks (Adobe Illustrator CS5.1) based on a story of a Belgian tourist (Belgium is the country where I studied arts) visiting Greece, with the title "Holidays in Greece". These open files can be printed at any size for any application (not for commercial use). These will be send to you via e-mail.

The Impact

  • I don't know if you ever felt so close and at the same time so far from the dream of your life…
  • I don't know if you ever got close or lived with an artist and felt his passion…
  • I don't know if you ever felt that you have one and only goal…
  • This is heaven, this is hell, this is ART!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to contribute financially please make some NOISE by SHARING.
THANK U

story:
Updates!

21/02/2013 - Yes! I got my first step to my campaign here. ($31/$50000) Hopefully more will come . Please support me more!! 

About Myself

I am a freelance digital artist.I have been drawing for almost
20 years of my life, from Pencil and paper to now tablet and photoshop.


My Deviantart Site is digitalmake.deviantart.com / Please check out for more of my artwork i have done previously.

About My Campaign

I wanted to setup a digital art studio to provide people with art. There are a lot of people out there like me who is out of job, and who love to draw and paint a lot.


I hope i can setup a small studio and hire them as my artist and we can work together as an artist. At the same time, they can work and earn by working on their hobby.

What will I do in order to get this happen

Basically, i will update few days later with the interior design of my new office and its floorplan. Get more local people who need art for their business and look around for applicants of digital artist who love ART.

What will my Studio look like?

Floor Plan of my Office ( which is about 320 Sq ft ) 

This will be the frontdesk of my studio.

This will be my office.

 

This will be my staff and artist office.

**note that the above images is only a draft design of my office , i will update more on the design in this few days time. 

 

- My office will include a Artist's Office, Washroom, Meeting Room, Front Desk and My own office . 

- More of the interior design will be out soon . please stay with me. 

What do i need

- 3 Imac = $5000 USD

- Software ( Photoshop,3dsmax and some graphic softawares ) = $3000

- Renovation Cost = $24050

- Cost to Hire Artist and Admin = $8000

- Office Furniture and Acessories = $10000 

- Admin Stuff and Company Licencing = $5000

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By setting up a studio, I need a lot of stuff to be done. I need at least 3 Imac, get graphic software, rent an office, and renovate the small office.


For all these, I need at least a $60,000 USD in order to do so, plus admin salary, company registration license and so .

I need to raise at least $50000 in order to do so as i still got some saving with me for the remaining amount.

This amount is just an estimated amount of the needs to setup a small company. I will consider doing a milestone for you guys to support me even more (if needed).

What you will get

For 1USD funding - A Small name of yours to be in my future artwork.

For 25USD funding - I will draw a portrait for you

For 50USD funding - I will draw a half body character of your                   choice + with simple background.

For 100USD funding - I will draw a full body character in detail of your choice + with simple background.

For 200USD funding - I will draw a full body character in detail of your choice + with detailed background.

For 2000USD funding - I will draw 10 full body character in detail of your choice + with detailed background. + a print out on every artwork i done for you with my signature to be deliver to your address.

For 10000USD funding - I will draw 15 full body character in detail of your choice + with detailed background. + a print out on every artwork i done for you with my signature to be deliver to your address.

+A name of you and a picture of you on my Artwork in the future.
And Additionally i will invite you to my office once it is launch here.

**I will post all the artwork that i deliver to you here for updates.

Other Ways you can help me

You can help me to spread the words around to help me (facebook, twitter).

 

 

THANK YOU VERY MUCH FOR YOUR GREAT SUPPORT!!

story:
We would like to raise your attention and get your help for our art festival LaBa! that will take place on May 25th, 2013, on Mackinnon Road in Kampala, Uganda.
We, the Goethe-Zentrum Kampala/ Ugandan German Cultural Society (GZK/ UGCS), are a non-profit local NGO based in Kampala, Uganda, and with a group of committed Ugandan artists we will carry out the festival for the 7th time in a row. It has become an important event in the cultural calendar for the whole country and has even been mentioned in the latest Lonely Planet guide for Uganda!

Now why, if LaBa! is such a success, would we think of asking you guys for money? Shouldn’t we have enough? No. Due to economic instabilities in the world and especially in Europe, it is very hard to get sponsors for this year’s event. Some of our long-time supporters don’t see a way to be on board this time.

It’s a shame because this year we are trying out a new concept. The theme “Open Studio” challenges artists to actually produce something in public and to interact with the audience rather than exhibiting or selling their finished products. LaBa! is open for all art genres. The festival doesn’t take place behind closed doors or in an elitist setting but on an ordinary street in Kampala. It therefore encourages people to take part in it who wouldn’t usually attend an art festival. With LaBa!, art comes to the people.

In order for it to take place without a loss of quality, we ask you for your help. Your contribution is not a donation for us as a cultural society but for the Ugandan artists and their ideas to make the festival come to life.

 

Please also have a look at our youtube channel:

http://www.youtube.com/user/GoetheZentrumKampala !

 

---

 

Wir möchten eure Aufmerksamkeit auf unser Kunstfestival LaBa! richten (25. Mai 2013 in Kampala, Uganda) und euch um Hilfe bitten! Wir, das Goethe-Zentrum Kampala/ Ugandan German Cultural Society (GZK/ UGCS) sind eine gemeinnützige ugandische Nichtregierungsorganisation mit Sitz in Kampala, Uganda. Mit einer Gruppe engagierter Künstler tragen wir das Festival in diesem Jahr zum siebten Mal in Folge aus, das sich national als wichtiges Event im kulturellen Kalender etabliert hat und sogar im aktuellen Lonely-Planet-Reiseführer erwähnt wird.

 Warum, aber, wenn LaBa! ein solcher Erfolg ist, bitten wir euch um finanzielle Unterstützung? Sollten wir nicht genug Geld haben? Leider nein. Weil überall auf der Welt das Geld knapp ist, war es in diesem Jahr besonders schwierig, genügend Sponsoren anzuwerben. Einige unserer langjährigen Partner sahen keine Möglichkeit, in diesem Jahr wieder dabei zu sein.

 Für dieses Jahr haben wir unser Konzept überarbeitet: Das Motto „Open Studio“ fordert die Künstler dazu heraus, ihre Kunst vor Ort zu kreieren und die Zuschauer daran teilhaben zu lassen – anstatt bloß fertige Produkte auszustellen. LaBa! ist offen für alle Kunstsparten. Das Festival findet nicht hinter verschlossenen Türen oder in einem elitären Umfeld statt, sondern auf offener Straße in Kampala. Auf diese Weise lockt es Menschen an, die ansonsten kaum mit Kunst in Berührung kommen würden. Mit LaBa! kommt die Kunst also zu den Menschen.

Damit das Festival ohne qualitative Kompromisse stattfinden kann, bitten wir euch um Hilfe. Damit unterstützt ihr nicht uns als Kulturorganisation, sondern helft letztendlich unseren ugandischen Künstlern dabei, ihre Ideen zu verwirklichen.

 

Schaut euch auch unseren Youtube-Kanal an:

http://www.youtube.com/user/GoetheZentrumKampala

story:
My name is Cory Ball, and I was born and raised in Indiana. I have been a professional body piercer among other things for 11 years - basically all of my adult life, and was recently involved in a situation that not only cost me my job - the best job I'd ever had -, it cost me my entire livelihood, but has also cost me my entire life as I know it. 

Due to my choices, my wife and I are separating after a 13 year relationship and 7 year marriage. I have no other option than to relocate to the only other family I have in this world, in South Florida, simply because in being employed in such an industry it makes it hard to do things like work and function like normal people can. Body modification can make someone unemployable, and such is the case for any normal job. 
So I have decided to take this opportunity to not mope around, not do foolish things that will hurt my family that I can never take back, but to move on in a positive light and embrace this new life, and Id love to take you along with me the entire way. I want to document this new life and post it all to YouTube for my children and all of you to enjoy. 

I am the type of person who hates to ask for handouts, and want to be completely transparent throughout this entire process, In my time I have made a lot of good money doing my work, and will continue. For now due to this situation I am unable to work, and that's why I'm asking here.

The plan is to purchase a go-pro hero 4 silver and a mount, which comes to a grand total of $469.98 shipped free to me, and for me to have this and be able to document all this change for my children would be huge, but I also want to create a channel that will show my travels. I plan to travel the country/world  and do body suspension, piercing, and body mods all along the way, as well as attend any  experience I can take in, and would love to have anyone interested to tag along.  If you donate to this, and if you so please I will be more than willing to travel to you while in your area, and work on you as well at a greatly reduced rate.  If all the funds aren't met, I will prove that the money donated will go towards the camera and only the camera. I have no desire for any sort of monetary gain, and will refund as well upon request if funds aren't met.

The impact of me being able to get this camera without having to completely sell any my possessions would be so great, as I am doing so now to make ends meet while I remain with my family (out of the kindness of my wife for us to have a normal holiday season). The choices I have made were selfish and have completely torn apart my marriage, and in having to go, this may be one of the only things I can positively bring out of this in the near future. 

In the wake of all the recent happenings I have completely lost direction. I want to turn this negative into a positive and document it all along the way.  

We are all visitors to this time, this place.

We are just passing through.

Our purpose here is to observe, to learn, to grow, to love...

And then we return home.

With your help I can capture all the beauty the world has to offer through my eyes.

And hey I totally get it if you cant donate, but there are other ways to help. You can share this, and you can remember to love and be loved. Never forget that, and never forget who loves you

Will you come along with me?

story:
I,m Terry Cripps a painter and photogarpher.

Each year my budget for materials gets larger and this year I have an extra need.

My trusty Olympus camera has gone the way of all technology and failed, stopped, want work.

Without materials there is no painting, painting in the head really doesn’t sell very well. Without the camera to record my work and do photographic work like reportage and still life, half of my creative output ceases and the other half does’t get seen.

I need to replace the camera body, replenish my paints and brushes and buy material to paint on.

This has become much more important as I am at last in negotiations for a show in a major public London Gallery - more of that as the campaign goes on. At this time in my life this is a really big thing.

I need to raise £1500. First to replace the camera body and second to buy materials.
The camera body will cost £600 paint costs between £7 - £12 a tube and brushes anything unto £45 for large ones. You can tell the remaining £900 does not go far and we haven’t talked about paper or framing yet. Your help will get me a long way towards financing this.

A camera has two functions in my work, as tool and as a creative resource. As a tool it allows me to record and publish my work, you can see these at Blurb.co.uk, just enter my name. It also allows me to produce limited edition prints of selected work, itself a means to raise funds. One of which I shall be offering to contributors.

As a creative resources I photograph a lot. Reportage mainly but also still life. This close observation informs my painting even though it is abstract I couldn’t paint without it.

The hope is that this new exhibition will incorporate both disciplines in one show so I need to get working to prove to the curator that the idea can work, but whether it is painting or photography or both they will all play their part.   

Your contributions will contribute greatly to making this project happen and be the highlight of my career. Opportunities like this happen rarely and I intend to make the best of this one.

Previously I have financed my own shows. Last year I exhibited twice. First ‘The Source’ at the national River and Rowing Museum in Henley on Thames which was of paintings in response to the character of the Thames and in the autumn a collection of tulip photographs called ’Neo Tulip’ at the Chipping Camden Theatre, Oxfordshire.

It is exhibitions like these I believe that have lead to this opportunity in London.

Even if you can’t contribute you may know someone who might. Please spread the word.
story_txt: I,m Terry Cripps a painter and photogarpher.Each year my budget for materials gets larger and this year I have an extra need.My trusty Olympus camera has gone the way of all technology and failed, stopped, want work.Without materials there is no painting, painting in the head really doesn’t sell very well. Without the camera to record my work and do photographic work like reportage and still life, half of my creative output ceases and the other half does’t get seen.I need to replace the camera body, replenish my paints and brushes and buy material to paint on.This has become much more important as I am at last in negotiations for a show in a major public London Gallery - more of that as the campaign goes on. At this time in my life this is a really big thing.I need to raise £1500. First to replace the camera body and second to buy materials.The camera body will cost £600 paint costs between £7 - £12 a tube and brushes anything unto £45 for large ones. You can tell the remaining £900 does not go far and we haven’t talked about paper or framing yet. Your help will get me a long way towards financing this.A camera has two functions in my work, as tool and as a creative resource. As a tool it allows me to record and publish my work, you can see these at Blurb.co.uk, just enter my name. It also allows me to produce limited edition prints of selected work, itself a means to raise funds. One of which I shall be offering to contributors.As a creative resources I photograph a lot. Reportage mainly but also still life. This close observation informs my painting even though it is abstract I couldn’t paint without it.The hope is that this new exhibition will incorporate both disciplines in one show so I need to get working to prove to the curator that the idea can work, but whether it is painting or photography or both they will all play their part.   Your contributions will contribute greatly to making this project happen and be the highlight of my career. Opportunities like this happen rarely and I intend to make the best of this one.Previously I have financed my own shows. Last year I exhibited twice. First ‘The Source’ at the national River and Rowing Museum in Henley on Thames which was of paintings in response to the character of the Thames and in the autumn a collection of tulip photographs called ’Neo Tulip’ at the Chipping Camden Theatre, Oxfordshire.It is exhibitions like these I believe that have lead to this opportunity in London.Even if you can’t contribute you may know someone who might. Please spread the word.

story:
WHO ARE WE?

As current students in the Special Events Planning Program at George Brown College, we were tasked with planning a charitable event. Art In The 6ix supports youth artists in the Greater Toronto Area with 100% of all donations going towards AFCY (Arts for Children and Youth) and the George Brown College Foundation.

WE NEED YOUR HELP

We are currently working with a limited budget as the school does not provide us with any monetary support. All money donated goes directly to putting on this event as we are hoping to raise $2,000 for our charities.

Toronto is a very diverse city with local artists who deserve to be showcased and appreciated. This event will shine a light on their talent and bring awareness to two great local charities in Toronto.

WHAT IS ART IN THE 6IX?

This event will primarily consist of visual and performance art. There will also be featured live performances from Carter Behnke and DJ FeelGoodSmalls. During the show there will be a silent auction that will consist of all the displayed artwork as well as sponsored gift baskets at our raffle table. At this 19+ event, we have included passed hors d'oeuvres in the ticket price, and will have a cash bar on site. 100% of all profits from Art In The 6ix will go evenly to the George Brown Scholarship Fund, as well as AFCY.

WHEN IS ART IN THE 6IX?

The event will take place on Thursday, February 12th, 2015 from 7:00 - 10:00PM. 


Tickets to Art In The 6ix are now available!!


Follow us!   

  • Instagram
  • Facebook
  • Twitter

story:
Short Summary

School of Service began in 1971 and has grown steadily since, evolving into the thriving Access Arts program of today.  Our mission is to provide creative learning experiences for everyone.  We offer instruction in a variety of art media, with an emphasis on serving those who are underserved.  

Each summer, we pair up local celebrities with local artists. Each celebrity gets to pick the medium s/he wants to learn, and we match them with an artist who is skilled in that area. The artists teach the celebrities how to make something (paintings, drawings, sculpture, etc.) and each pair has a filmmaker document their work.

The culminating event is called CelebrARTy. This annual fundraiser helps Access Arts achieve its mission throughout the year by raising valuable operational funds.  You’re invited to join us for a spectacular evening including a heavy appetizers and drinks reception where the celebrities’ masterpieces will be auctioned off and patrons will get an exclusive first look at the documentaries created during the process.  This year’s CelebrARTy will be hosted at Dogmaster Distillery on October 29. 


What We Need & What You Get

Our fundraising goal is $10,000. This campaign will help us cover the cost of all those up-front expenses that come with hosting our event:  Artist and Filmmaker Stipends, Venue rental, Art supplies, Art Framing & Display materials, Food and Beverages, etc.  Any amount we receive in addition to our campaign goal will help to sustain Access Arts’ work throughout the year. Our work helps thousands of participants who span across age groups, racial lines, social classes, and various stages of ability. 

To help make this campaign extra special, all of the perks offered are handmade items by the community of artists who love and support the work we do.  The perk you receive will be totally unique, unlike anyone else's.  

The Impact

CelebrARTy was born from a conversation about our mission.  We wanted to host an event that would embody our mission’s four components:  Creative, Learning, Experience, and Everyone.  We believe that all four of these components are equally important, but it seems that it is the Everyone part that is the hardest to uphold.  So many people say, “Oh, I’m not an artist!  I don’t have a creative bone in my body!” Yet our world needs creative problem solvers to tackle complex issues that affect us all.  We believe that this barrier of “I’m not creative” can be overcome.  We intentionally choose celebrities that are well-known and respected in their professional areas of expertise--areas NOT typically viewed as creative or artistic.  They are our examples, showing that if So-and-So (i.e. professional athlete, politician, newspaper editor, etc.) can make art, anyone can: even you!  We take away their intimidation by pairing up celebs with an artist mentor to guide them. This personalized instruction demonstrates the value of quality art instruction amidst today’s plethora of D.I.Y. Pinterest tags and You Tube videos.  We see the impact of such instruction in our classrooms every day, as individual students develop skills and interact with people of differing backgrounds, exploring new ideas and possibilities.  Creative Learning is essential for building healthy communities.  CelebrARTy is our way of putting this issue in the spotlight, demonstrating its potential, and having fun in the process.  You as a contributor can be a part of changing the way our society views art education.

Risks & Challenges

Organizing a group of celebrities, artists, filmmakers, and event logistics staff is quite an undertaking.  Since each person has a career, family, and other obligations to juggle, it is difficult to coordinate schedules and ensure the artwork and videos are completed before the event.  We have a dedicated planning committee comprised of board members, Access Arts staff, and other volunteers who have years of experience with event planning.  The individuals on this committee work closely with each artist-celeb-filmmaker team, assisting them with the unique needs of their projects (procuring supplies, scheduling studio space, etc.) to streamline the process and keep the projects moving forward.

Given that these celebrities are quite busy and in high demand, the biggest challenge we face is their limited time.  We begin our conversations with potential participants by describing the time commitment expected of them and our deadlines for completing their work.  By outlining these things from the beginning, a celebrity can realistically estimate whether s/he can complete the project. 

Of course, no matter how much you plan, sometimes things just come up.  Last year, in the middle of his painting lessons, one of our celebrities, Kim English, was called to Chicago to begin training with the Chicago Bulls. Such hurdles always arise with large-scale projects, but all of our celebrities are committed to finishing their projects and supporting our mission. Together with our planning committee, any problem that comes up can be solved.  In Kim’s situation, we arranged for his remaining lessons to be done via Skype and his artwork was shipped back for the auction.  Kim valued his own experience with his artist mentor so much that he even scheduled a flight back to Columbia to attend the auction in person.   

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute in dollars and cents? Access Arts is always looking for enthusiastic volunteers to help keep our mission alive, our facilities functional, and our community vibrant. We also welcome donations of materials and supplies, and are always looking for new partnerships to elevate our existing programming. Share this campaign with your friends to give it the extra boost it needs to meet our goal!

story:
About Our Project

Down Right Original Puppets (D.R.O.P.) Circle Tour. We are a group of puppeteers, musicians, and artists traveling around Lake Superior and performing a puppet show based on the importance of the Lake Superior watershed. We have experience with smaller puppet shows but this will be the first tour we take. We have received a grant to help us with the funding, but we need to match that amount in order to make our journey possible.

What We Need

We are in need of raising an additional $1000. The funds will go directly to transportation costs, building supplies, and location booking fees. Any additional funds raised will go into an account to help make future shows possible.  By helping us reach our goal, we will be able to provide a positive educational experience for community members of towns around the lake.  If we do not reach the goal of $900, we will no receive the grant funding needed to make this happen.  

The Impact

Our goal of this project is to foster community in the towns that we visit. We will be performing outside by the lake front (weather permitting) and inclusive to all spectators. The theme of the show tackles our relationship with the watershed, the history of the lake, the story of a drop of water, and the relationship of the lake to its ecosystem. We hope that the show encourages exploration and creates a ripple of creativity to the people it serves.

Our team has been working together for 4 years to provide free, community based puppet shows in Northern Wisconsin. We hosted monthly shows at our home for over two years and played around with a ride variety of puppetry styles and techniques.

Help Us Share Our Dream

Please help us spread the word about our journey and performances. If you can make it out to any of our shows, please come! Encourage others to come out! If you know of anyone who would love to support our efforts, please pass this info along to them.

This project is supported in part by a grant from the Chequamegon Bay Arts Council and the Wisconsin Arts Board with funds from the State of Wisconsin.

story:
Short Summary

Sugar Land Art Center & Gallery is proud to be a 501c3 non-profit organization. Our mission is to provide a supportive, positive, and fun atmosphere for the community to
experience art, whether through classes, private lessons, a studio space to
create in, or participation in one of our camps or workshops.

We are always trying to find new ways to grow, and better serve the community, however in order to achieve the expansion we hope for, we need your support. Our growth is not possible without the support and donations of our friends and business contributors.


In order to keep our classroom rentals and Kidz Art Kamp tuition low enough to be accessible to the entire community, we need some support. Your donation in any amount will be used to ensure the continuation and growth of our summer art camp programs. We will bring in new teachers, more supplies for extra projects, and additional scholarships to ensure that our program truly is available to the entire
community.

We anticipate a very exciting year at Sugar Land Art Center and Gallery, with the growth of our new gallery space, and more classes and workshops available than ever before. Thank you for being a part of all these exciting changes.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our main fundraising goals:

  • Improved signage on the building so that people can find us
  • Advertising so that the community knows about the different programs we offer for adults and children
  • Kidz Art Kamp supplies & scholarships
  • New chairs, tables, and easels for the classrooms
  • Plumbing and ventilation for our kitchen

What our donors will receive:

  • $25 - You will be mentioned on our "donors and supporters" page of our website, plus a hand-written thank you note.
  • $50 - With your $50 donation, you'll receive a "Random Acts of Artwork" starter kit, with Artist Trading card blanks, paints, pens, and more to help you start your own RAA movement, plus a feature on the "donors" page of our website, and a handwritten thank you note.
  • $100 - a 10 pack of blank cards, featuring a variety of work by students in our Kidz Art Kamp, plus a mention on our website and a hand-written thank you note.
  • $250 - a custom 12x12 piece of art from one of our artists, plus a mention on our webpage and a hand-written thank you note.
  • $700 - a custom 16x20 piece of art from one of our artists or a special 2-hour event in our gallery for up to 20 people (local donors only), plus a mention on our webpage and a hand-written thank you note.
  • $1500 - A custom quilt created by nationally acclaimed, award winning fiber artist Nichole Webb Rivera, plus a mention on our webpage and a hand-written thank you note.

The Impact

Every contribution makes a huge difference. We strive to provide as many services as possible to the entire community, and every donation we receive can help create a new project or improve an existing one to ensure that we are reaching the most people possible. These donations will be used to improve our facility, and to improve the quality of supplies we provide during all of our children's workshops, while keeping the costs of these workshops low enough that everyone has the chance to come and learn with us.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you're able to send a donation or not, you can help! Please share this will all of your friends, and on social media. The more people we can reach with this campaign, the more people in the community we can help through art. So spread the word!

story:
Liquid Heat is a Public Art and Community Project for East Harlem, New York City.   

The Art Project

Photographer Jessica Angel is collaborating with the renowned New York City based dance company - Ballet Hispanico - to create a series of vibrant photographic images of Latin dance. The images are printed on architectural scale canvases to create a series of installations in streets across el Barrio.  The images will both reflect and nurture the vibrant Hispanic culture of El Barrio by connecting with the existing mural art trail. The work will animate the streetscape and architecture bringing the energy of dance to the fore and bring the dance from the streets, via the theatre, back to the streets.

The ‘show’ will be an invitation to discover the ‘art trail’ through Manhattan. The works will be installed in a temporary exhibition throughout the spring and summer of 2015.

Liquid Heat will develop a website presence to bring the images to a wider public.  With recordings of poetry by the Puerto Rican poet Luis Pales Matos  – there will be an animated photographic montage and short film on the website to reach the broader Latin American and Caribbean communities and convey the essence of the wider project. 

The Community Project

In parallel to the Art Project is  the outreach programme that will foster community engagement.  This will feature an artist's residency at Ballet Hispanico leading to a photographic competition for the young students of Ballet Hispanico. The students come from marginalised Hispanic communities across New York City. They will be invited to capture the spirit of Latino dance in their classes and in their families and home neighbourhoods and look at their dances and culture through a different lens.  We will invite our key partners (Ballet Hispanico & key local Community partners) to select and curate a series of images which form a key component of the art trail.  The images will be displayed on the bus furniture, buses and information boards on the bus routes running between 96 Street and 120 Street, and across town.  These images will visually link with the large-scale works.

This element of the project will form part of a sustainable legacy achieved through this exciting international and pan-Hispanic project.

Why this project?

This is a highly visual, high impact public art project, which is all about:

  • Acknowledging and celebrating Latino Culture and achievement
  • Raising aspiration, imbuing a sense of pride and recognising achievement
  • Engaging young people and providing them with an opportunity to view their dance and culture through a visual lens.
What we need!

We need to raise 65,000 US dollars to get this project developed. The funds will cover:

  • The artist residency in New York to capture the images which will feature on the Art Trail -  flights, accommodation, film and a fee for the artist
  • The development of the website  - covering design costs
  • The establishment and shaping of the community program, which will take the form and a youth photographic project to capture the spirit of dance in the Hispanic neighbourhoods. 

The funds we raise will be prioritised to cover the immediate project costs, the photographic costs and artist fees.

The other ways you can help us are...

  • Sponsoring return flights between London and New York
  • Sponsoring an apartment hire or loan in New York.  
  • Passing on the details of this project to anyone who would be interested in supporting it
  • Spreading the word and promoting this amazing project!

The Team

Our great team includes our print company Concorde Graphics who provided the mock-ups, film-maker Jon Cheetham who made our promo, Eduardo Vilaro - Artistic Director of Ballet Hispanico and the amazing dancers and Tom Lunke of Harlem Community Development Corporation who has guided and advised us. 

As a team we have an exemplary track record of delivering creative, community and large-scale public art projects on an international scale. We bring expertise and match it to expertise on the ground in Spanish Harlem in order to bring global recognition and weight to a site-specific celebration of East Harlem's Latino communities.

Liquid Heat will develop a website presence to bring the images to a wider public.  With recordings of poetry by the Puerto Rican poet Luis Pales Matos  – there will be an animated photographic montage and short film on the website to reach the broader Latin American and Caribbean communities and convey the essence of the wider project. 
The Community Project
In parallel to the Art Project is  the outreach programme that will foster community engagement.  This will feature an artist's residency at Ballet Hispanico leading to a photographic competition for the young students of Ballet Hispanico. The students come from marginalised Hispanic communities across New York City. They will be invited to capture the spirit of Latino dance in their classes and in their families and home neighbourhoods and look at their dances and culture through a different lens.  We will invite our key partners (Ballet Hispanico & key local Community partners) to select and curate a series of images which form a key component of the art trail.  The images will be displayed on the bus furniture, buses and information boards on the bus routes running between 96 Street and 120 Street, and across town.  These images will visually link with the large-scale works.
This element of the project will form part of a sustainable legacy achieved through this exciting international and pan-Hispanic project.
Why this project?
This is a highly visual, high impact public art project, which is all about:

Acknowledging and celebrating Latino Culture and achievement
Raising aspiration, imbuing a sense of pride and recognising achievement
Engaging young people and providing them with an opportunity to view their dance and culture through a visual lens.
What we need!

We need to raise 65,000 US dollars to get this project developed. The funds will cover:



The artist residency in New York to capture the images which will feature on the Art Trail -  flights, accommodation, film and a fee for the artist


The development of the website  - covering design costs


The establishment and shaping of the community program, which will take the form and a youth photographic project to capture the spirit of dance in the Hispanic neighbourhoods. 


The funds we raise will be prioritised to cover the immediate project costs, the photographic costs and artist fees.
The other ways you can help us are...

Sponsoring return flights between London and New York
Sponsoring an apartment hire or loan in New York.  
Passing on the details of this project to anyone who would be interested in supporting it
Spreading the word and promoting this amazing project!
The Team
Our great team includes our print company Concorde Graphics who provided the mock-ups, film-maker Jon Cheetham who made our promo, Eduardo Vilaro - Artistic Director of Ballet Hispanico and the amazing dancers and Tom Lunke of Harlem Community Development Corporation who has guided and advised us. 
As a team we have an exemplary track record of delivering creative, community and large-scale public art projects on an international scale. We bring expertise and match it to expertise on the ground in Spanish Harlem in order to bring global recognition and weight to a site-specific celebration of East Harlem's Latino communities.

story:
THE Shoe Boxes are there!!!

Yes!! this is what they look like!! The Shoe Boxes, and they have been dropping into the Shoe Box Collective´s post boxes over the last week!! The first Phase is now underway! ART is being made!!


About me and "The Art in Shoe Box Project". 

My name is Mara Barth, I am passionate about art and culture, especially collaborative projects. I enjoy bringing people from different disciplines together to explore creative approaches and perspectives. The shoe box project will be a representation of this type of dialogue. The limited space of the shoe box challenges the artist and a highly concentrated and intimate form of creativity and art will be captured.  

My MA project. 

"Art in Shoe Boxes" is the reflective project for my MA in Culture and Creative Enterprise at Queen Margaret University, Edinburgh. Applying the skills I have learnt throughout the course I will work as the project manager of the "Art in Shoe Box Project", bringing together creative perspectives and approaches throughout Europe. This project gives us the opportunity to explore collaboration in the arts and develop new and innovative ideas and experiences.   

The art in Shoe Box Collective.

The shoe box collective has already been formed. The collective consists of artists from countries throughout Europe. When the artists finishes working in the box he/ she passes it on to another member of the shoe box collective, a swap takes place and each artist responds to whatever they find inside the box. The exchange between the artist will be limited to the space inside the boxes, introducing an unusual form of collaboration, The space and the work nurtures the dialogue. 

The artists are from the UK, Ireland, Germany, France, Portugal, Latvia, Czech Republic etc.  

They are sculptors, writers, fashion designers, photographers, poets, visual artists, painters and wonderful people.

The funding.

The funding I am asking for will cover the postage costs of the shoe boxes, allowing for a wider and culturally dynamic approach. The budget also includes marketing such as flyers, posters and cards for the continuous development of the project and will also ensure visibility for the artists and the exhibition. 

Become part of the shoe box project: the fun perks will allow you to keep a small personal piece of the shoe box project, a post card, a poster or a very special photo book. Your contribution will give artists the opportunity to work together and show their work in Edinburgh, giving them a wider visibility and widening the cultural and artistic community in Europe.  Through sharing the work with each other and then with you, the artists build a powerful example of collaboration and conversation. 

To show my appreciation and respect for the artists and their work, any funding which exceeds the goal will be equally divided between the participating artists. 

Make some noise!!!


If you can't contribute, please help us by making some noise and sharing this link. Once the process part of the project is completed (the shoe boxes have been returned) a facebook page and webpage will be setup to continue the journey, please do find us and like us and keep believing in and spreading the power of creativity. 

If you have any questions or are interested in receiving regular process updates throughout the project, please email me at artinshoeboxes@gmail.com.

Thank you

Mara!

story:
My Story:

My name is Mary Lessing.  I am a painter and print maker from Indianapolis, IN.  As far back as I can remember I have wanted to do art for a living.  I have been pushed and encouraged by my art teachers, professors, and peers to pursue it.  I have a Bachelors Degree in Illustration and Painting from Indiana Wesleyan University. 

Leaving college, I had the same naive optimism that any graduate has.  15 years later, I am still working part time and doing art on the side.  My husband and I scrape by and support our boys, but working part time is an absolute necessity for me to pay bills.  I work hard at my job and at my art.  I stretch myself thin lots of days.  Its worth it to keep creating and making great art.  I would love to make a huge push forward!

I have an amazing opportunity to do art FULL TIME!  I have been accepted into a tattoo apprenticeship.  If you know anything about apprenticeships, you will know that they are very difficult to get.  Anyone thinking that tattooing isn't an art...I may not convince you.  It is coming into the mainstream in a major way and is seen as fine art by many, including myself. This will be a fabulous opportunity to grow as an artist and to use my gifts in order to support my family more.  This truly would be a dream job!

What I need:

I need to raise funds in order to pay for the training and to purchase my supplies.   $2000 is to pay for the training and $1500 for supplies.  $3500 total!

What you get:

I have lots of art perks to give out for donations to my fund.  I have handmade lino prints of many styles and colors.  I am also offering some custom pencil and oil and watercolor painting portraits.  For photos of perks please look through my gallery.  If you are interested in a custom piece please contact me for details on what you want painted.  You can also take a look at my behance site to see the kind of work I have created in the past to give you an idea of what I do.   If you have any questions about perks please ask. 

The impact you will make:

The donations that you make will have a lifelong impact on me and my family.  I will be learning a marketable skill that I can use to support my family.  If my boys are interested in art, it may even be a skill I can pass on to the next generation so they can have a better start than I did.

Other ways you can help:

Please feel free to share my campaign with your friends and family and anyone who loves the arts or tattooing.  

Even if I don't get fully funded, all support will help me reach my goal! 

Thanks so much for looking and sharing!
